feed.title: Geometry Club
feed.subtitle: Celebrating the beauty of architecture with precisely aligned photographs from around the world.

entry.title: Best of 2018
entry.content: A round-up of my personal favourite Geometry Club submissions from 2018. A huge thanks to everyone who contributed this year!
entry.summary: A round-up of my personal favourite Geometry Club submissions from 2018. A huge thanks to everyone who contributed this year!

entry.title: Mini Series: Welbeck Street car park, London.

link.title: Mini Series: Welbeck Street car park, London.

entry.content:
Welbeck Street car park is one of London’s most iconic brutalist-era landmarks. The multi-storey building was designed by Michael Blampied & Partners and completed in 1970. With it’s geometric modular facade, made up of 100+ concrete diamond-shaped frames, this building is a must-see when in London. However, time is of the essence as Westminster Council recently approved the demolition of this architectural classic to make way for a 10-storey hotel.

Thanks to those who has submitted their shots of it so far (below). If you’re lucky enough to stand beneath it before it’s demolished, snap my favourite composition, submit, and i’ll add them here, too.
entry.summary: Welbeck Street car park is one of London’s most iconic brutalist-era landmarks. The multi-storey building was designed by Michael Blampied & Partners and completed in 1970. With it’s geometric modular facade, made up of 100+ concrete diamond-shaped frames, this building is a must-see when in London. However, time is of the essence as Westminster Council recently approved the demolition of this architectural classic to make way for a 10-storey hotel. Thanks to those who has submitted their shots of it so far (below). If you’re lucky enough to stand beneath it before it’s demolished, snap my favourite composition, submit, and i’ll add them here, too.

entry.title: Best of 2017
entry.content:
What a year!

Creative Review interviewed me and wrote a wonderful piece about the project. The article made it all the way into their February 2017 issue. Other notable (printed) praise came at the kind hands of Surface Magazine, The Observer, and The Guardian.

I redesigned this website, with an emphasis on simplicity and ease-of-use. Particularly for those accessing it on mobile devices.

Finally, to round the year off, (iOS developer) Alexander Edge and I released the Geometry Club iOS app — A free iPhone and iPad camera application that helps you to align your architecture photos with precision.

As always, thank you for supporting, contributing to, and sharing the project! Please take a look at my personal favourite Geometry Club photos from 2017. (below)

All the best for the new year!
entry.summary: What a year! Creative Review interviewed me and wrote a wonderful piece about the project. The article made it all the way into their February 2017 issue. Other notable (printed) praise came at the kind hands of Surface Magazine, The Observer, and The Guardian. I redesigned this website, with an emphasis on simplicity and ease-of-use. Particularly for those accessing it on mobile devices. Finally, to round the year off, (iOS developer) Alexander Edge and I released the Geometry Club iOS app — A free iPhone and iPad camera application that helps you to align your architecture photos with precision. As always, thank you for supporting, contributing to, and sharing the project! Please take a look at my personal favourite Geometry Club photos from 2017. (below) All the best for the new year!

entry.title: Creative Review Article
entry.content:
I was recently interviewed by Creative Review about how Geometry Club began and what’s coming up. I’ve bought dozens of issues of CR over the last ten years, so for the project to be celebrated by them is undoubtedly my favourite achievement to date.

Thanks to all of you for contributing, supporting, and making it possible.

Here’s a link to the full article online.
entry.summary: I was recently interviewed by Creative Review about how Geometry Club began and what’s coming up. I’ve bought dozens of issues of CR over the last ten years, so for the project to be celebrated by them is undoubtedly my favourite achievement to date. Thanks to all of you for contributing, supporting, and making it possible. Here’s a link to the full article online.

entry.title: Best of 2016
entry.content:
Looking back at Geometry Club this past year has made me immensely proud. Geometry Club has been highlighted by some of my favourite blogs in design/creativity; Aisle One and Swiss Miss. The Barbican Centre got in on the act and did a mini-series of their own ‘Geometry Clubs’. Oh, and Sweet did a really cool piece on Snapchat about us which, i later learned, was the reason we got 3 or 4 thousand new followers in one day.

I’ve got some exciting things in the pipeline for 2017. (Including an iOS app to help you line-up that shot with perfection, but more about that later).

Thank you to everyone who’s followed along so far and a high-five to those of you who have contributed to #geometryclub. I literally couldn’t do it with y’all.

Here’s my personal favourite twelve shots of 2016. Happy New Year!

Here’s my personal favourite twelve shots of 2016. Happy New Year!

entry.title: Mini Series: The Broad Museum, LA.

link.title: Mini Series: The Broad Museum, LA.

entry.content:
The Broad is a new contemporary art museum founded by philanthropists Eli and Edythe Broad on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles. The museum is designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro in collaboration with Gensler.

Since it’s opening in September 2015, The Broad Museum has been the most photographed piece of architecture that i’ve received submissions for on Geometry Club. I can’t feature every submission of The Broad. But, as it’s such a charming building, here’s a little mini series that i’ll keep updating as the submissions roll in.

Enjoy!
entry.summary: The Broad is a new contemporary art museum founded by philanthropists Eli and Edythe Broad on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles. I can’t feature every submission of The Broad. But, as it’s such a charming building, here’s a little mini series that i’ll keep updating as the submissions roll in. Enjoy!
